fields: {{c1::Marginalization}} (Summing Out) is the process of getting $P(A)$ from a joint table $P(A, B)$ by summing across all values of $B$.
Concept Check: Use this when you want to 'remove' a Hidden Variable.
The {{c1::Product Rule}} (General Law) states that $P(A, B) = {{c2::P(A|B)P(B)}}$.
Works for all events, even dependent ones. Do not confuse with Independence ($P(A)P(B)$).
In Bayes' Rule, the {{c1::Prior}} $P(Y)$ is belief before evidence, while the {{c2::Posterior}} $P(Y|E)$ is belief after evidence.
The Likelihood is $P(E|Y)$. Denominator $P(E)$ is used for normalization.
{{c1::Bag of Words (BoW)}} represents text as a vector of word counts where vector size always equals {{c2::Vocabulary Size ($V$)}}.
Crucial Property: It destroys Word Order ('Dog bites man' = 'Man bites dog').
Naïve Bayes 'Naïve' Assumption: Words are {{c1::independent}} given the {{c2::label}}.
Math Fix: We sum logs ($\sum \log P$) instead of multiplying probabilities to prevent underflow.
The classification loss function {{c1::Negative Log Likelihood}} (Cross-Entropy) uses a negative sign because {{c2::logs of decimals are negative}}.
We need a positive 'Error' value to minimize during Gradient Descent.
{{c1::One-Hot Vector}}: A vector of vocabulary size where one bit is 1 and all others are 0.
Used for input, but huge and sparse.
A {{c1::Token}} is the integer index of a word in the vocabulary.
Tokens are inputs for Embedding Layers; One-hots are inputs for Linear Layers.
The {{c1::Hidden State}} acts as a bottleneck, forcing the network to learn {{c2::generalizations}}.
